summary: This is a transcript of a June 16, 2021, DOJ Office of the Inspector General interview with a former Bureau of Prisons lieutenant regarding the circumstances surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's death at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. The interview focuses on the witness's knowledge of Epstein's required cellmate status, the release of his cellmate Reyes, and whether proper notifications and procedures were followed.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The high-profile inmate who died by suicide in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center on August 10, 2019. The interview centers on the failure to ensure he had a cellmate as required after his previous cellmate was released.

persons.name: Reyes
persons.context: The inmate specifically assigned to be Jeffrey Epstein's cellmate after Epstein came off suicide watch. He was released from MCC after a court appearance on August 9, 2019, leaving Epstein without a cellmate.

persons.name: Captain Darden
persons.context: The captain at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. The interview discusses whether he was notified about Reyes's release and who had authority to assign a new cellmate to Epstein.

persons.name: Tova Noel
persons.context: A correctional officer who worked the morning watch shift (10:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m.) at MCC. The interview questions whether she was required to and did conduct rounds in the SHU.

persons.name: Michael Thomas
persons.context: The activities lieutenant who relieved the witness on August 9, 2019. The interview questions whether the witness informed him that Reyes had been released and Epstein was without a cellmate.

connections.description: Reyes was specifically assigned to be Epstein's cellmate after Epstein came off suicide watch, as Epstein was required to have a cellmate at all times.
Captain Darden, as the captain, should have been notified about Reyes's release from the institution and should have been involved in deciding who Epstein's new cellmate would be.

Noel was a correctional officer on the morning watch shift when Epstein died. The interview establishes that she, like all lieutenants, was required to conduct rounds in the SHU, which would have included checking on Epstein.

events.title: Reyes released from MCC
events.description: Epstein's assigned cellmate, Reyes, was taken to court and released from the Metropolitan Correctional Center, leaving Epstein alone in his cell contrary to suicide watch protocols.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. The death was ruled a suicide.

events.title: OIG Interview of former BOP Lieutenant
events.description: The Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General conducts a sworn, recorded interview with a former BOP lieutenant regarding his knowledge and actions surrounding Epstein's death.

events.title: Previous FBI/OIG/AUSA Interview
events.description: The witness was previously interviewed by the FBI, OIG, and an Assistant U.S. Attorney in August 2019 regarding the Epstein matter. The 2021 interview seeks to clarify discrepancies from that earlier interview.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), 150 Park Row, New York, New York
keyFacts: The witness, a former BOP lieutenant, disputes a prior interview report that stated he knew Epstein's cellmate Reyes was not coming back and was waiting for the captain to assign a new one. He claims he only knew Reyes left for court, not that he was permanently released.
Policy required a lieutenant to conduct rounds 'down range' with inmates in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at least once per shift, which should have included checking on Epstein.

The institution received a call at 1:50 PM on August 9, 2019, notifying them that Reyes was not returning from court. The witness claims he did not receive this notification before his shift ended at ~2:00 PM.

The witness states that any inmate on suicide watch, like Epstein had been, is required to have a cellmate at all times, and this policy was covered in both quarterly SHU training and annual refresher training.
The witness attributes Epstein's death to a systemic failure: 'people just didn't do their job,' citing multiple potential points of failure in communication and procedure.
